importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, and was reported in the article as part of the timeline of events at Hong Kong International Airport.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The aircraft skidded off the runway at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, marking the precise moment of the incident as reported in the article.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a patrol vehicle.
The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with significant damage to the front section and tail section, and was left partially submerged.
All four crew members were treated for injuries and are confirmed safe, with no cargo on board.
The aircraft did not transmit any distress signals during approach, and the airport authorities reported no prior alerts from pilots.
The incident prompted a large emergency response involving over 200 people, fire engines, and boats.
Airport operations on the north runway were suspended, but the other two runways remained operational, preventing major disruptions to flights.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major airlines.
This incident highlights the rare occurrence of fatal aviation accidents at one of the world’s busiest airports, despite its high traffic volume.
The airport has a history of safety challenges, including a major crash in 1999 at Kai Tak Airport, which was once considered one of the world’s most difficult for landings.

namedEntities.name: Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international airport located on an island about 20 miles west of Hong Kong’s Central district.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The incident occurred at HKIA, where the cargo plane skidded off the runway and crashed into the sea, affecting operations and safety protocols.

namedEntities.name: Boeing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The aircraft involved in the crash was a Boeing model, indicating the type of aircraft involved in the incident.

namedEntities.name: ACT Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Turkish cargo carrier that operates cargo aircraft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ACT Airlines operated the cargo plane involved in the incident and is identified as the operator of the aircraft that skidded off the runway.

namedEntities.name: Emirates
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The flight was assigned an Emirates flight number, although the aircraft was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, indicating a contractual or operational partnership.

namedEntities.name: Steven Yiu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive Director of Airport Operations at Hong Kong International Airport.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided official statements about the incident, including the details of the collision with the patrol car.

namedEntities.name: Wesley Yung
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Technical chief at Hong Kong’s Civil Aviation Department.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He confirmed that no distress signals were received from the pilots during the approach, which is relevant to assessing the circumstances of the crash.

namedEntities.name: Kai Tak Airport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The former airport in Kowloon City, Hong Kong, now demolished.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is referenced historically as one of the world’s most difficult airports to land at, providing context about Hong Kong’s aviation safety history.

namedEntities.name: China Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major airline based in Taiwan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is mentioned in the historical context of a 1999 crash at the former Kai Tak Airport, which contributed to understanding the airport’s past safety challenges.

namedEntities.name: Patrol car
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was struck by the aircraft and resulted in two fatalities, making it a central element in the human impact of the incident.

namedEntities.name: Runway
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A designated area at the airport for aircraft takeoff and landing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The aircraft skidded off the north runway, prompting a suspension of operations on that runway.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) around 3:50 a.m. local time, crashing into the sea and killing two occupants of a nearby airport security patrol vehicle. The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with significant damage to its front and tail sections. All four crew members were treated and confirmed safe, with no cargo on board. The aircraft did not transmit any distress signals during approach, and the incident triggered a massive emergency response involving over 200 personnel. Operations on the north runway were suspended, though other runways remained operational, minimizing flight disruptions. The flight was under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines. This event underscores the rarity of such accidents at Hong Kong’s busy airport, despite historical challenges associated with previous airport locations like Kai Tak, where a major crash occurred in 1999.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
